title: Pink Anderson
text:
Pinkney "Pink" Anderson (February 12, 1900 – October 12, 1974) was an American <a href="blues">blues</a> singer and guitarist.
Life and career.
Anderson was born in <a href="Laurens%2C%20South%20Carolina">Laurens, South Carolina</a>, and raised in nearby <a href="Greenville%2C%20South%20Carolina">Greenville</a> and <a href="Spartanburg%2C%20South%20Carolina">Spartanburg</a>. He joined Dr. William R. Kerr of the Indian Remedy Company in 1914 to entertain the crowds, while Kerr tried to sell a concoction purported to have medicinal qualities. During this time Anderson occasionally worked with <a href="Blind%20Simmie%20Dooley">Blind Simmie Dooley</a> in the Spartanburg area, recording with him in 1928 for the <a href="Columbia%20Records">Columbia</a> label. In the 1950s Anderson toured with Leo "Chief Thundercloud" Kahdot and his medicine show, often with the harmonica player Arthur "<a href="Peg%20Leg%20Sam">Peg Leg Sam</a>" Jackson, who was based in <a href="Jonesville%2C%20South%20Carolina">Jonesville, South Carolina</a>.
Anderson was recorded by the folklorist <a href="Paul%20Clayton%20%28folksinger%29">Paul Clayton</a> at the Virginia State Fair in May 1950.
He recorded an album in the early 1960s and performed at some live venues. He appeared in the 1963 film "<a href="The%20Bluesmen">The Bluesmen</a>". He reduced his activities in the late 1960s after a stroke. Attempts by the folklorist Peter B. Lowry to record Anderson in 1970 were not successful, although apparently he could occasionally summon up some of his past abilities. A final <a href="concert%20tour">tour</a> took place in the early 1970s with the aid of <a href="Roy%20Book%20Binder">Roy Book Binder</a>, one of his students, taking him to Boston and New York City.
He died in October 1974 of a heart attack, at the age of 74. He is interred at Lincoln Memorial Gardens, in Spartanburg.
Anderson's son, known as <a href="Little%20Pink%20Anderson">Little Pink Anderson</a> (born July 13, 1954), is a bluesman living in <a href="Vermillion%2C%20South%20Dakota">Vermillion, South Dakota</a>.
The Pink in Pink Floyd.
<a href="Syd%20Barrett">Syd Barrett</a>, of English <a href="progressive%20rock">progressive rock</a> band <a href="Pink%20Floyd">Pink Floyd</a>, created the band's name by juxtaposing the first names of Anderson and <a href="North%20Carolina">North Carolina</a> bluesman <a href="Floyd%20Council">Floyd Council</a>.
